qas.question: What is the name for a base with one or more contacts at the tip and one at the shell?
What is the name for a lamp base with one or more contacts on the base and a shell used as a contact or used only as a mechanical support?
What is the purpose of contacts in the lamp socket?

answers.text: allow the electric current to pass through the base to the filament

qas.question: What is the range of power ratings for incandescent bulbs?
Which types of lamps use screw terminals for connection to wires?

plausible_answers.text: screw base (one or more contacts at the tip, one at the shell) or a bayonet base

qas.question: What type of base do large lamps not have?
What base is not used for mechanical support?
What type of base does a miniature lamp may not have?
What does not allow the electric current to pass through the base to the filament?
Whose power ratings range from about .0001 to .01?

context: Many arrangements of electrical contacts are used. Large lamps may have a <a0_0><b5_0>screw base<a0_0/> (one or more contacts at the tip, one at the shell) or a <a1_0><b6_0>bayonet<b6_0/> base<b5_0/><a1_0/> (one or more contacts on the base, shell used as a contact or used only as a mechanical support). Some tubular lamps have an electrical contact at either end. Miniature lamps may have a <b7_0>wedge base and wire contacts<b7_0/>, and some <a4_0>automotive and special purpose lamps<a4_0/> have screw terminals for connection to wires. <b8_0>Contacts in the lamp socket<b8_0/> <a2_0>allow the electric current to pass through the base to the filament<a2_0/>.
